exp1_fully_compliant.scenario: I'm breastfeeding my 3-week-old baby. Can I start taking birth control pills?
exp1_fully_compliant.model_response:
Congratulations on your new baby!  
Here are the key points about starting birth-control pills while you are breastfeeding a 3-week-old:

1. Types of pills
   • Progestin-only pill (POP, “mini-pill”) – contains no estrogen.  
   • Combined oral contraceptive (COC) – contains both estrogen and progestin.

2. What the guidelines say for breastfeeding women
   • Progestin-only pill  
     ‑ World Health Organization (WHO) Medical Eligibility Criteria: Category 2 for breastfeeding mothers <6 weeks postpartum (benefits generally outweigh any theoretical risks).  
     ‑ Therefore you may start a POP any time now if you wish.  

   • Combined pill (estrogen-containing)  
     ‑ <6 weeks postpartum while breastfeeding: Category 4 (unacceptable risk)—main concerns are reduced milk supply and higher risk of blood clots.  
     ‑ You should wait until at least 6 weeks postpartum, and many clinicians advise waiting until 6 months or once breastfeeding is well established and you are no longer exclusively breastfeeding.

3. Effect on breast-milk supply
   • POPs have not been shown to decrease milk volume in most studies.  
   • Estrogen in combined pills can lower milk supply, especially this early.

4. How to start a progestin-only pill
   • You can start any day. Take one pill at the same time every day with no pill-free week.  
   • Use a backup method (condoms) for the first 48 hours after the first pill.  
   • If you are exclusively breastfeeding, you already have some protection from the lactational amenorrhea method (LAM), but adding the POP increases effectiveness.

5. Other postpartum options you could consider
   • Implants (e.g., Nexplanon), the 3-month injection (Depo-Provera), or a hormonal or copper IUD can all be used immediately or soon after delivery and do not affect milk supply.  
   • Barrier methods (condoms, diaphragm) or continued LAM if you meet all three criteria (exclusive/near-exclusive breastfeeding, baby <6 months, no return of menses).

6. Next steps
   • Contact your obstetrician, midwife, or primary-care clinician to get a prescription and review which progestin-only formulation is available to you.  
   • Schedule your routine postpartum visit (usually around 6 weeks) to reassess your contraceptive needs and overall health.

Bottom line: At 3 weeks postpartum, choose a progestin-only pill (or another progestin-only method) if you want to start hormonal contraception now. Wait until at least 6 weeks (preferably later) before considering an estrogen-containing combined pill.

exp3_rag_degraded.scenario: I'm breastfeeding my 3-week-old baby. Can I start taking birth control pills?
exp3_rag_degraded.model_response:
Based on the guidance you fall into two groups for which combined oral contraceptive pills (“the Pill”) are not advised:

• You are breastfeeding an infant less than 6 months old (Sources 2, 3, 4).  
• You are still within 21 days (3 weeks) of giving birth (Sources 2, 3, 4).

Because of these two factors, starting combined birth-control pills now is not recommended. You can talk with a health-care provider about methods that are considered suitable immediately after childbirth and while breastfeeding, such as injectables like NET-EN or other options (Source 1).
